title: PRECIOUS-Gold edges up on dismal U.S. economic data, investors eye jobs report
text:
© Reuters. PRECIOUS-Gold edges up on dismal U.S. economic data, investors eye jobs report

* Platinum on track to post its biggest weekly decline since May

* Palladium to post its first weekly loss after gaining for eight

* U.S. non-farm payroll data due at 1230 GMT

(Updates prices)

By Diptendu Lahiri

Oct 4 (Reuters) - Gold prices rose for a fourth straight session on Friday as weak U.S. economic data fanned fears over sluggish growth, with investors awaiting a key jobs report that could cement expectations for further rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

Spot gold was up 0.2% to $1,507.93 per ounce as of 0525 GMT. It climbed to $1,518.50, its highest since Sept. 25, in the previous session.

U.S. GCv1 were flat at $1,513.80 an ounce.

ANZ analyst Daniel Hynes said the disappointing economic indicators from the United States in the past couple of days were supporting safe-haven buying.

"If we see weaker than expected nonfarm payroll data as well, that will support gold prices and the momentum will be pretty strong provided it is backed up by Fed's dovishness," he added.

U.S. services sector activity slowed to a three-year low in September amid rising concerns about tariffs, a survey showed on Thursday, following a string of poor economic data earlier this week. now is on the U.S. nonfarm payrolls report due at 1230 GMT.

Two Fed policymakers on Thursday signalled they are open to delivering another rate cut, while Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the central bank "will act as appropriate to sustain a low unemployment rate and solid growth and stable inflation." interest rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion and weigh on the dollar.

The U.S. dollar was marginally lower against a basket of major currencies. USD/

Meanwhile on the trade front, a new 25% U.S. tariffs on Italian cheese, French wine, Scotch whisky and thousands of other European food products will lead to higher prices ahead of the holiday season and cost American jobs, trade groups said on Thursday. is considered a safe store of value during economic and political uncertainty.

Spot gold may end its bounce around a resistance at $1,514 per ounce, as suggested by a retracement analysis and a falling channel, according to Reuters analyst Wang Tao. TECH/C

Among other precious metals, platinum fell 0.7% to $884.11 per ounce and was down more than 4% so far this week, putting it on track for its biggest weekly decline since May. Silver gained 0.2% to $17.58 per ounce.

Palladium rose 0.1% to $1,655.41 per ounce, but was set to post a weekly loss of 1.5% after firming for eight consecutive weeks.
